text:
*[Bug 18690] Increase CONSOLE_BUFFER_SIZE and / or warn if input is truncated*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18690>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|CONFIRMED                   |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED

--- Comment #3 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I've now improved the handling of very long lines also in Rgui. Rgui no longer
introduces newlines in input lines longer than the console buffer size. Also,
handling of long lines with multi-byte characters has been improved, previously
they could include garbage.

Now it is possible to paste lines with unlimited length also to Rgui console
(with some inherent drawbacks of that the line editor works on segments of a
line but doesn't allow full editing of lines of arbitrary length). Allowing
full editing of lines of arbitrary length would probably not be worth the extra
effort.

text:
*[Bug 18416] Gentoo Linux fails stats test on RISC-V platform*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18416>

Michael Orlitzky (<mailto:michael@orlitzky.com|michael@orlitzky.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |michael@orlitzky.com

--- Comment #13 from Michael Orlitzky (<mailto:michael@orlitzky.com|michael@orlitzky.com>) ---
In 2022 it was rare, but real RISC-V hardware is becoming widely available now.
I'm got one of these,

  * <https://milkv.io/pioneer>

and there are a few end-user laptops shipping with SpaceMIT motherboards:

  * <https://deepcomputing.io/product/dc-roma-risc-v-laptop-ii/>
  * <https://arace.tech/products/muse-book-risc-v-laptop>

In addition to those, there will soon be a RISC-V mainboard for the Framework
laptop:

  *
<https://frame.work/blog/introducing-a-new-risc-v-mainboard-from-deepcomputing>

Finally, the new Raspberry Pi RP2350 boards have RISC-V processors on them
(I've got one in my DEF CON badge):

  * <https://www.raspberrypi.com/products/rp2350/>

It seems like you completely understand the issue and are making a decision
based on time/effort, which I understand & can't complain about, but I wanted
to stop in and say that in a few years this won't be weird hardware for weird
people any more.
